(4/3)*3=(4*3/3) by (4/3)*(3/1) to (4*3)/(3*1) or 12/3, simplifying to 4.  Y=(4/3x)+4+2 (the 2 from the Y_1 and 4 from (4/3)*3 when the (4/3) distributed to the (x-x_1) term in the point slope formula.  Simplify: Y=(3/4x)+6, where b is 6 in slope intercept form  The video likely covered the formula, but I put this here to as a friendly reminder.  P.S. This is my first comment I've written on YT.

College has a vague meaning in the US.  College actually is like a form of post secondary education which is pretty much just university but less intense. This is the college they are referring to in the video.  Generally though, people like to use the term college to refer to both actual college and university. It can be pretty confusing.  Btw college and university both start once you have graduated high school and are 18 (or older)

@wavez4224  thanks. So it is vague, it's always confused me. College in the UK is an alternate to university, often more trade related, often night courses with only months to a few years Vs university 3+ years full term.

@sparkequinox  yea it’s like that here in Canada too. I was confused about what college meant in America too for a long time cuz we use the terms differently here too.  I think part of it might be just cuz it’s easier to say “where did you go to college?” Then “where did you go to university?” Cuz the people who went to college will feel bad when u ask the second one but the people who went to university don’t care

@wavez4224  makes sense.   In the UK we don't really have that negative view as most education is made sure to follow a minimum quality that tends to be pretty good. I can only imagine how US public college can vary so much. My US cousin at 16 came to study here for a few months and it was clear her education level was years behind ours (particularly maths). It makes sense why US university students all take base courses throughout their degree then "major" in something. So different but so interesting to know.

Great question We can’t simplify because when either the denominator (bottom) or the numerator (top) have addition AND/OR subtraction we can’t reduce, but if they had ONLY division or multiplication in BOTH then we can reduce.  For example  (1x+2)(3x+9) ——————— (1x+2)(4x+1) Is reducible to  (3x+9) ———- (4x+1) Because these are strictly undergoing multiplication  (3x+2)- 1 ————— (3x+2) Is not reducible because of subtraction. @bryan8038  For most high schools in Serbia this is taught from grades 1 to 3. In the 4th grade (and a little in the third) we learned Calculus. This applies to High schools where math is taught all four years. I attended Gymnasium and my sister attended Medical school, so we both learned it like this, the only difference is that I learned it in much more details (I had 4 math classes per week, while she had 2). But the lessons are pretty much the same, so for example she learnt derivatives and integrals in the fourth grade, just like me.

In the UK, we do this at 16/17 if you do maths with a bit at 17/18 then we go further. As well as every other category of maths, including calculus. Americans do more subjects at the same time though in high school, so I guess it's quantity over quality.
